content:
Hello there Maxime


Let me explain to you why there is nothing for this solution. Thunderbird has integrated this dark theme option into your Software and is not available as an add-on.

Previously, there was an abundance of solutions to offer you this in the form of add-ons.

This is more dilapidated, while the add-ons that you want to help you are there but are out of date.

You can switch the dart theme to a light theme.

There are also tricks, for example on YouTube, that may shed some light on these topics.

Unfortunately, it currently does not have the option to provide all kinds of colors that are exchanged for the well-known dark theme that was once introduced on a previous version of Thunderbird.

Now that Supernova has replaced these outdated versions, it is also a change in itself for everyone.

And I don't see the option you want if I want to get that for you.

You can contact me back After Reading this.


Greetings Firefox volunteer

content:
You have to accept cookies in TB Settings/Privacy & Security, for OAuth2 authentication to work. OAuth2 should be the authentication on the incoming and outgoing (like here).

Remove the entries for the account from Saved Passwords in Settings, restart TB, enter the account password in the OAuth window, which will store an oauth:// token in saved passwords, used for both incoming and outgoing.

You can create a new profile from Help/Troubleshooting Info, about:profiles, without affecting the old profile. Data like local mail and address books can be transferred from the old to the new, and once the old profile is no longer needed, it can be removed in about:profiles.

content:
The gmail smtp server settings are as follows and they work perfectly for an imap gmail account using Authentication Method: OAuth2 I know because not only have I been using one set up for a few years in version 102.15.1 But I've also just - and I mean about 10 minutes ago - added an imap gmail account in beta 119.0b6

SMTP outgoing

  • Server name: smtp.gmail.com
  • Port: 465
  • Connection SEcurity: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: OAuth2
  • User Name: full email address
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Gmail imap account is now very easy to set up and that includes connecting to gmail calendar.

But you did not mention what type of account you use, settings etc Is it a Pop or IMAP mail account ? Do you use Authentication Method: 'OAuth2' or 'Normal Password' for both incoming and outgoing? Have you set up to use 2FA and therefore use an app specific password ? In which case, you have to alter things from the default settings - eg: Authentication Method: has to be 'Normal Password' but you actually enter the app specific password.

If using the default settings Authentication Method:OAuth2 then you would have to disable that 2FA and not use any app specific password. Enter normal password at gmail prompt so a token gets created, stored and used by Thunderbird from then onwards.

Oauth2 is set up for incoming and outgoing at the same time, so if eg: outgoing had a problem then you would need to remove all passwords, restart Thunderbird to force a login to google which then means you can allow Thunderbird access to account.

In addition - set up your Firewall to allow Thunderbird program so no ports get blocked.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Toad-Hall said
Gmail imap account is now very easy to set up and that includes connecting to gmail calendar. But you did not mention what type of account you use, settings etc Is it a Pop or IMAP mail account ? Do you use Authentication Method: 'OAuth2' or 'Normal Password' for both incoming and outgoing? Have you set up to use 2FA and therefore use an app specific password ? In which case, you have to alter things from the default settings - eg: Authentication Method: has to be 'Normal Password' but you actually enter the app specific password. If using the default settings Authentication Method:OAuth2 then you would have to disable that 2FA and not use any app specific password. Enter normal password at gmail prompt so a token gets created, stored and used by Thunderbird from then onwards. Oauth2 is set up for incoming and outgoing at the same time, so if eg: outgoing had a problem then you would need to remove all passwords, restart Thunderbird to force a login to google which then means you can allow Thunderbird access to account. In addition - set up your Firewall to allow Thunderbird program so no ports get blocked.


I was using the standard settings for Gmail configuration - but could not get it to work. I finally found a solution - that was to change Connection Security to STARTTLS instead of SSL/TTS (which was the standard) This happend on multiple of my google accounts - using different OS'es (Fedora & Windows). One is without 2FA, one is with 2FA enabled - no app specific password used with the one with 2FA enabled.

I don't know why SSL/TTS isn't working, but it's working now with STARTTS.

Now I'm wondering why STARTTS works but SSL/TTS don't :)

content:
Post this info:

In Thunderbird Help > Troubleshooting Information Scroll down to 'Mail and News Accounts' Copy all the data in that section and paste it into this question in forum. OR upload an image showing the information.

Authentication issue means one of the following is wrong. Server Settings are wrong or correct but set for wrong email address. Lack of authentication when it's required Password wrong or password is correct but not with those server settings. It also depends upon whether you use pop or imap. So lets start by checking if you have the correct server settings. It also tells us what servers you are dealing with. Some servers have changed what type of password they expect eg: some now insist on using Oauth or an app specific password, but we can advise this when we know what server you are trying to use.

content:
Here is the information that you asked for.

content: To clarify, account 16 and 19 are the ones with the issues.
creator: jagassoc

content:
First logon to webmail account for first yahoo email address. Please make sure 2FA is switched off https://help.yahoo.com/kb/SLN5013.html

Then do the same for the other yahoo account.

Back in Thunderbird. account16 (imap) imap.mail.yahoo.com:993 SSL/TLS OAuth2 smtp.mail.yahoo.com:465 SSL/TLS Normal password true account19 (imap) imap.mail.yahoo.com:993 SSL/TLS OAuth2 smtp.mail.yahoo.com:465 SSL/TLS OAuth2 true

yahoo using imap must use 'Oauth2' for both incoming and outgoing. If yahoo had 2FA switched then it is expecting an app specific password and thunderbird sends either wrong email address or wrong user name or the normal password or an oauth token it will fail to authenticate. Equally, if you have switched off 2FA and you try to connect using normal password or app specific password or wrong account username - it will fail to authenticate.

AS both are using same server then you also need to check that both are actually using their own smtp server. So I suggest you perform every step I mention below in the order stated because we need to make sure everything is correctly aligned.

Do this:

  • Account Settings
  • Left Pane scroll to bottom and below 'Local Folders' - click on 'Outgoing Server (SMTP)'
  • It will list all your outgoing servers.
  • You should have two smtp servers for the yahoo accounts.
  • Select the first yahoo smtp
  • Click on 'Edit'
  • Description: type the email address which should be the same as the User name
  • Authentication Method: set as 'Oauth2'
  • User name: full email address - check for any typos
  • click on 'OK'
  • Select the second yahoo smtp
  • click on 'Edit'
  • This should have a different User name/email address to the previous one.
  • Description: type the email address which should be the same as the User name
  • Authentication Method: set as 'Oauth2'
  • User name: full email address - check for any typos
  • click on 'OK'

Now to make sure each one is using their own.

  • In left pane select first yahoo mail account name
  • look bottom right for 'Outgoing Server (SMTP):'

The 'Description' will display the email address Does it match the name of the selected account ? If no:

  • click on the drop down and select the correct one
  • DO NOT Click on the 'Edit SMTP_Server' button because we need to make sure the correct one is actually selected in the first place.
  • In left pane select second yahoo mail account name
  • look bottom right for 'Outgoing Server (SMTP):'

The 'Description' will display the email address Does it match the name of the selected account ? If no:

  • click on the drop down and select the correct one
  • DO NOT Click on the 'Edit SMTP_Server' button because we need to make sure the correct one is actually selected in the first place.

Now to check account name is correct in server incoming

  • In left pane select 'Server Settings' for first yahoo account
  • Check 'User Name' : full correct email address - no typos
  • Repeat same for second yahoo mail account.

Now to check cookies are enabled and remove the password - I suggest you do one account at a time as it means you know which account requires which password.

  • Settings > Privacy & SEcurity

'Web Content'

  • Select 'Accept cookies from sites'
  • 'Accept cookies from sites: select 'Always'
  • Scroll to Passwords
  • Click on 'Saved Passwords'
  • Click on 'Show Passwords'

For one particular yahoo email address - select anything where the user name = that email address and click on 'Remove'. You may have up to 3 items: imap://account...smtp://account... and also oauth://account... click on 'close'

Then Exit Thunderbird. Wait a few moments for background process to complete then start Thunderbird

You should get a pop up and yahoo should ask for email address and normal password you use when accessing the webmail account, for the account/email address which you deleted the stored password, so you can allow Thunderbird to access server.

Then you need to access 'Settings' > 'Privacy & Security ' > 'Saved Passwords again and this time remove everything to do with the other yahoo email address/user name.

Then Exit Thunderbird. Wait a few moments for background process to complete then start Thunderbird

You should get a pop up and yahoo should ask for email address and normal password for that other yahoo username /email address which you deleted.

REport back on results.
creator: Toad-Hall

That was a pain in the neck. I really don't want to have to do that again.

content:
It would be really useful if you could keep me informed of the actiosn you did and the results. You mentioned that you had not used the two step authorisation - it was not switched on in either account.

Did you actually perform every single step I asked you to do in the order I stated because you do not mention that you worked though everything absolutely as I stated? You cannot skip any step. When you altered the 'Description' in each smtp and then checked which the account was using...did you find each account was already using correct smtp server or did you need to reselect either of them ? Did you get the yahoo Oauth pop up sign in to allow authentication ? Was the cookies option set to allow and for always ? Do you now see new emails ?

re: not saving to Sent or Drafts

Account Settings > Copies & Folders for each account. Have you selected for Sent 'Other' and choose eg: 'Sent on mail account' and the Drafts 'Other' and choose eg: 'Drafts on mail account'
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Yes, as I stated, the two-step authorization was never switched on for either account. Yes, I performed the steps in order as you instructed. As for the "Description" I had to correct each of them to reflect what you instructed me that they should be. But they were both using the correct smtp server. Yes, I got the Yahoo Oauth pop up. Yes the cookies were set to "allow" and "always" which they already were.

So, after doing all of that and trying it multiple times I got fed up with using so much of my time I decided to shut my computer down. I was going to try to access my e-mails on another computer using Thunderbird but that ended up being a bigger headache that I won't go in to. So, I turned my main computer back on and voila the e-mails are working again.

I don't know if this is a coincidence or not (I don't believe in them anyway) but before I shut my computer off Windows was telling me that I had to restart it to load an update. Now I have been getting those messages frequently over the last several months (don't know why). I have restarted my computer every time I had gotten those messages usually after a few days but anyways this time I hadn't restarted it before the e-mail issues came up. Also, the same e-mail issues came up I think the last time it happened a few years ago after I did a Windows update. I don't know if these things have anything to do with the issues.

The bottom line is I am back up and running for now. Thank you for your help.
creator: jagassoc

content:
On the old computer: Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Folder, close TB, copy the mbox files - the large files with no extension, named after folders, in Mail/<popservername>, Mail/Local Folders, ImapMail/<imapservername>, and any of their .sbd subdirectories, to an external drive.

On the new computer: Help/Troubleshooting Info, Profile Folder, Open Folder, close TB, copy the mbox files from the old computer into Mail/Local Folders, renaming them if necessary. Restart TB and find the folders under Local Folders in the Folder Pane.
creator: sfhowes

content:
Set up the account as IMAP on all devices so all the mail folders are synced across all devices. POP accounts only download the Inbox, and the Sent and other folders are stored only on the device on which they were created.

http://kb.mozillazine.org/Convert_a_POP_account_to_a_IMAP_account

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/imap-synchronization
creator: sfhowes

content:
Pat Murphy said
sfhowes, I created a new GMAIL account with a similar account name. I selected IMAP instead of POP and I do not have the problem. I am ow going to have to abandon my POP account (heavily used) and move everything over to the new IMAP account. It seems to me the Thunderbird 115.3.3 has an issue with POP server settings. Have you created a POP account to test this and can you send emails using LISTs using the POP account? I think someone in support needs to prove POP works with LISTs or make a statement the POP & LIST are not supported in Version 115.

Since you already showed the issue is only with the Hotmail POP account, I'd suggest first trying it with a Hotmail IMAP account, which you can add without removing the Hotmail POP account. Settings are the same, except the incoming is port 993.

One other thing: try it without any spaces in the list name, as this has been an issue in the past.

content: By username, I presume you mean the email address. That is on the account pane and in the Outgoing Server (SMTP) pane. To change the password, I suggest going to settings>privacy&security, click 'saved passwords' and then 'show passwords', followed by highlighting the two rows for the account, rightlclick and delete. Then, when you request new messages, you will be prompted for the password, which TB will then store for you.
